awd_titl_txt: Improving Introductory Physics for Life-Science Students through a Biomedically Relevant Multimedia Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest by improving physics instruction for life science and pre-health students.   These physics courses are generally taught by physics departments.  As a result, the courses often seem less relevant to these students unless the instructor and curricular materials explicitly connect to themes in the students' chosen majors. This project is a collaborative effort by Portland State University and Rockhurst University to develop a full year of modular, multimedia, biomedically-relevant educational material for use in physics courses. It addresses the important need to improve pre-health and life science physics curricula, with the aim of helping pre-health students appreciate the study of physics as both necessary and relevant to future biomedical careers. Design of the multimedia curricula will be accomplished through collaboration with biomedical professionals. The videos and supplementary materials adopt an active learning model based on real world applications to enhance interdisciplinary efforts and provide significant potential for increasing the learning that occurs in undergraduate physics. The significance of this project lies in addressing the need for future biomedical professionals to be well-versed in fundamental physics principles. These principles are involved in every aspect of analyzing functions of the human body, as well as the detection, diagnosis, and treatment of illnesses.  If successful, the project will contribute to a better prepared generation of healthcare professionals.

This project aims to transform Introductory Physics for Life Sciences education by filling two main needs. First, it will provide students with a curriculum that stresses the importance of physics as a basic science that is integral to medicine. Second, it will provide faculty with a coherent physics curriculum that can be implemented in multiple educational environments. These materials will be especially valuable to faculty members unfamiliar with biomedically-related interdisciplinary content. Curriculum materials developed in this project will include videos of interviews with biomedical experts, as related to the key ideas covered in an Introductory Physics for Life Sciences course. It will also include a written manuscript that will explicitly integrate videos with physics principles, and provide conceptual and quantitative pre/post class problems as well as formative and summative assessments.  To enhance use of the curriculum materials, the project will study their transferability to multiple educational environments. It will also examine the implementation of the curriculum with active learning pedagogies in introductory physics classrooms at both a large public university (Portland State University) and a small, liberal arts university (Rockhurst University). The project is designed to assess student content learning and attitudes toward learning physics.  Formative and summative assessment will be conducted through logging clickstream data, pre-post content assessment, attitudinal assessment, and focus group exit interviews.  The materials will be available to undergraduate physics teaching and education research communities without cost, for use on different digital learning platforms that enable students to complete assignments online, or in printed form for classroom or lab use.  The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Rockhurst University (RU) and Portland State University collaborated to enhance STEM education through the development of multimedia biomedically relevant educational material for introductory physics geared toward pre-health students. The main goals of the proposed project were to develop, implement, assess, and share curriculum with undergraduate physics teaching and education research communities as follows:

Aim 1: Design a full year of multimedia biomedical relevant introductory physics curriculum.

Aim 2: Implement curriculum with active-learning pedagogy at two different universities with different teaching environments.

Aim 3: Assess the effect of the curriculum on student learning and attitude.

Grant developed curriculum incorporates videos of interviews with biomedical experts as related to the key ideas covered in an introductory physics for life sciences (IPLS) course, a written manuscript to integrate videos with physics principles, conceptual and quantitative pre/post class problems, and formative and summative assessments.  To research transferability to multiple educational environments, biomedical curriculum was implemented with active learning pedagogies in introductory physics classrooms at RU, a small, liberal arts university and PSU, a large public university, and assessed for student content learning and attitudes toward learning physics. 

At RU, this grant supported efforts to develop a new biomedically relevant active-learning curriculum for introductory physics (BMP - Biomedically Relevant Physics) to provide a wider group of physics faculty with curricular materials to reform their intro physics classes to an active-learning physics course applicable for pre-health students.  Biomedically Relevant Physics (BMP) Chapters are designed to scaffold understanding as students build physics knowledge within a framework designed to enhance active processing of the material and biomedical relevance.  Emphasis is on the development of critical thinking and analysis skills, graphical interpretation, understanding of the importance of defining a system and scaffolding learning to build interpretive skills in physical settings.  

Curricular products developed at RU include five complete mechanics chapters consisting of following components:  1) Active Learning Text; 2) Learning Activities; 3) Biomedical Physics Expert Interview videos integrated into the curriculum; and 4) Assessment Questions tied to Learning Objectives.  Each chapter consists of 50 - 75 pages of active learning curriculum with integrated biomedical applications.  All curriculum is posted to the Living Physics Portal (LPP) in an editable form, complete with full instructor resources to support transferability of the curriculum to a wider physics audience.

Assessment of grant developed curriculum was designed to investigate both student attitude and student content learning of biomedically related introductory physics grant-developed curriculum.  Results indicated normalized gains in content as well as gains in attitudes toward the relevance of physics toward healthcare. Dissemination efforts included multiple national presentations, posters and workshops at the American Association of Physics Teachers National Meetings, two published papers, and contribution of curriculum to the Living Physics Portal.

Intellectual Merit:  The project contributed to STEM education through its research-based curriculum development.  The developed curriculum increased interdisciplinary knowledge and understanding in the IPLS field by addressing the need for a tested, assessed, biomedically relevant introductory physics curriculum designed to engage the large population of pre-health students in an appreciation of the study of physics as both necessary and relevant to their future careers in biomedicine.  The potential for transformation of introductory physics curriculum for this population exists in the curricular design to provide faculty unfamiliar with biomedically related interdisciplinary content with a coherent physics curriculum that can be implemented in multiple educational environments.  

Broader Impacts: The design of project multimedia curricula was based on collaboration with biomedical professionals in the production of videos highlighting the relationship of physics to biomedical professions.   Wide dissemination of biomedically relevant physics curriculum designed to engage pre-health students provides support for faculty new to teaching IPLS and is easily adaptable to different institutions and classroom pedagogies providing sustainability of this grant project.
